message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory findings suggest hemophilia, which is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Among the options, Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Alkaptonuria is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, sickle cell disease is inherited in an autosomal codominant pattern, and Huntington’s disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory results suggest a bleeding disorder, possibly hemophilia. This disorder is X-linked recessive, meaning it is more common in males and passed down from a carrier mother. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also X-linked recessive, and has the same mode of inheritance as hemophilia. Alkaptonuria is autosomal recessive, while sickle cell disease and Huntington's disease are autosomal dominant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prolonged bleeding and easy bruising suggest a bleeding disorder, and the laboratory results show a normal hemoglobin and platelet count, but an abnormal aPTT, which indicates a clotting factor deficiency. This is consistent with hemophilia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder. Duchenne muscular dystrophy also follows X-linked recessive inheritance. The other options have different modes of inheritance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has a history of prolonged bleeding and easy bruising suggests a bleeding disorder. The aPTT being fully corrected with a mixing study suggests that it is not a factor deficiency but rather a factor inhibitor or a factor produced poorly or not at all. Based on this information, the most likely diagnosis is hemophilia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also an X-linked recessive disorder, so it has the same mode of inheritance as this patient’s disease. Alkaptonuria is autosomal recessive and Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant, so they do not have the same mode of inheritance as this patient’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s prolonged bleeding and easy bruising suggest a bleeding disorder, and the normal platelets count and prolonged aPTT suggest a clotting factor deficiency, which can be caused by hemophilia. Hemophilia has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, which is the same as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Alkaptonuria is autosomal recessive, sickle cell disease is autosomal codominant, and Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant.

Among the options, only Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also an X-linked recessive disorder. Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder while sickle cell disease and Huntington's disease are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The laboratory results suggest a bleeding disorder, and the family history of bleeding problems is relevant. Among the options, Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the only disorder with an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, which could explain the family history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged bleeding and easy bruising suggest a bleeding disorder, which is likely hemophilia A or B. Both of these disorders are X-linked recessive, which means that males are more commonly affected and females are carriers. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also X-linked recessive, so it has the same mode of inheritance as hemophilia. Alkaptonuria and sickle cell disease are autosomal recessive, while Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the prolonged bleeding and easy bruising, suggest a bleeding disorder. The laboratory investigations, specifically the prolonged aPTT that is fully corrected with a mixing study, suggest a factor deficiency rather than a platelet disorder. This is most consistent with a hemophilia, which is an X-linked recessive disorder. Duchenne muscular dystrophy also follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern. Alkaptonuria and Sickle cell disease are both autosomal recessive disorders, and Huntington's disease follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The laboratory findings, along with the patient's bleeding and bruising history, suggest a bleeding disorder such as hemophilia. Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also X-linked recessive. Therefore, (C) Duchenne muscular dystrophy has the same mode of inheritance as this patient's disease. Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder, and sickle cell disease and Huntington's disease are autosomal dominant disorders.
